awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  New Constraints on Post-Glacial Rebound and Holocene Environmental History along the Northern Antarctic Peninsula from Raised Beaches
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description

Glacier ice loss from Antarctica has the potential to lead to a significant rise in global sea level.   One line of evidence for accelerated glacier ice loss has been an increase in the rate at which the land has been rising across the Antarctic Peninsula as measured by GPS receivers.  However, GPS observations of uplift are limited to the last two decades.  One goal of this study is to determine how these newly observed rates of uplift compare to average rates of uplift across the Antarctic Peninsula over a longer time interval. Researchers will reconstruct past sea levels using the age and elevation of ancient beaches now stranded above sea level on the low-lying coastal hills of the Antarctica Peninsula to determine the rate of uplift over the last 5,000 years.  The researchers will also analyze the structure of the beaches using ground-penetrating radar and the characteristics of beach sediments to understand how sea-level rise and past climate changes are recorded in beach deposits.  The benefits of these new records will be threefold: (1) they will help determine the natural variability of the Antarctic Ice Sheet and relative sea level (2) they will provide new insight about uplift and the structure of the Earth's interior; and 3) they will help researchers refine the methods used to determine the age of geologic deposits.   The study results will be shared in outreach events at K-12 schools and with visitors of the Santa Barbara Natural History Museum.  Three graduate students will be supported through this project.  

Technical description

Paleo sea-level data is critical for reconstructing the size and extent of past ice sheets, documenting increased uplift following glacial retreat, and correcting gravity-based measurements of ice-mass loss for the impacts of post-glacial rebound. However, there are only 14 sites with relative sea-level data for Antarctica compared to over 500 sites used in a recent study of the North American Ice-Sheet complex.  The purpose of this project is to use optically stimulated luminescence to date a series of newly discovered raised beaches along the eastern Antarctic Peninsula and an already known, but only preliminarily dated, series of raised beaches in the South Shetland Islands. Data to be collected at the raised beaches include the age and elevation, ground-penetrating radar profiles, and the roundness of cobbles and the lithology of ice-rafted debris. The study will test three hypotheses: (1) uplift rates have increased in modern times relative to the late Holocene across the Antarctic Peninsula, (2) the sea-level history at the northern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula is distinctly different than that of the South Shetland Islands, and (3) cobble roundness and the source of ice-rafted debris on raised beaches varied systematically through time reflecting the climate history of the northern Antarctic Peninsula.

por.por_cntn:
Satellites circling Antarctica suggest it is losing ice and this ice-loss is happening faster and faster. The melting ice has the potential to lead to a significant rise in global sea levels.  However, to make accurate predictions of potential future sea-level rise, the satellite-based measurements need to be corrected for processes that can only be measured directly on the Antarctic continent.  One of these corrections is the rate at which the land underneath the ice sheets is rising.  Previous estimates of how fast the land is rising are based largely on GPS observations.  However, GPS observations are limited to the last ~20 years and may miss long-term natural trends.  One way to learn how fast the land has been rising in the past is to study the Antarctic coast. As the continent rises, beaches are lifted to a higher level. Goal of this project was to measure ancient uplift rates by using the elevation and age of ancient beaches along the Antarctic Peninsula. 

The age of the beaches was measured with a method called Optically Stimulated Luminescence Dating or short: OSL. Cobbles that are at sea level are continually turned over by waves. Once a beach is raised to a higher level, the cobbles remain in place and the underside is shielded from sunlight. Small amounts of natural radioactivity in the rock and surrounding material cause radiation damage in the rock?s mineral grains. The damage increases over time. The rock can be collected in the dark and taken to the laboratory. When it is exposed to infrared light, the radiation damage heals, and some of the minerals glow faintly in blue light. This light is called luminescence or OSL. The longer the rock?s underside has been in the dark, the brighter it will glow. Thus the OSL can be used to measure the age of the beach.

81 rock and sediment samples were collected on Joinville and Livingston Islands for OSL dating. Quartz and feldspar minerals are most suited for OSL dating and those minerals were separated through chemical treatments. Minerals from different locations on Earth have slightly different chemical composition, which influences their luminescence. While quartz is usually well suited for OSL dating, the quartz from the collected samples did not emit any light. Some of the feldspar samples did not emit any light either, and only 48 samples were suitable for dating. Overall, samples from Joinville Island emitted more light than rocks and sediment collected on Livingston Island. Control samples collected from a modern (i.e. current) beach had ages of few years, as expected. Ages obtained with different approaches from the same sample are generally in very good agreement. Different samples from the same beach ridge often show large discrepancies and the possible reasons are manifold. Some of the samples had very dim signals and were not well suited for OSL dating. Several samples located on a high beach ridge (higher elevation means older age), have a near modern age. These samples had possibly been turned over by penguins or seals. Others have unreasonably high ages, and have likely not been exposed to sunlight while they were in the swash zone.

In total 3 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students were involved in the project, including three female students. One graduate student and three undergraduate students were financially supported by the project. Graduate students from different disciplines (physics and geology) worked together in a team. With their joint understanding of the OSL method and rock properties they were able to improve sample preparation methods.  All students gained valuable experience in working in an interdisciplinary team.
